messageBody:
Steve:

Thanks for your input. You obviously have studied this subject whereas I
am writing from personal beliefs without the benefit of such study.
I will interject a few comments on your e-mail below.

Steve Bett wrote:

> Hi Paige,
>
> Thanks for your comments. Paige wrote:
>
> > If I, as an American, can understand Australian English or British
> > English when spoken, I surely should be able to understand it when
> > written [phonemically] in QS.
>
> With a phonemic script one has two options,
> spell as you think you speak or spell a standard base dialect that
> nearly everyone understands.

> Standardization came about primarily because that is what publishers
> wanted. It is not a "hold over." Publisher's still want
> standardized spelling.

PG: What I meant by "hold over" was that was what was desired in the past
with T.O. I am not so sure it would be necessary in a new script relatively
closely connected to people's current speech patterns.

> Readers of the popular press would also prefer it because it permits
> them to ramp up their reading speed. It is not because they could
> not understand it if it were written in dialect that they could
> understand if they heard someone speak it.

PG: And this addresses one of the problems of any new alphabet: the dead
weight drag of those who are already literate. The metric system in the
U.S. faces the same problem. Alexander Graham Bell testified before
Congress over 100 years ago about how much sense adopting the metric system
made for the U.S. He might as well saved the cost of his train ticket for
all the good it did. Virtually no one will put in the time and effort to
learn a new system when they already know the old one, even if the old one
is much less efficient.

> The primary objection to any kind of spelling reform is not that it
> cannot be read but that it takes more effort and reduces reading
> speed.

PG: If on some remote island, you could introduce six year olds to QS from
the beginning, I have no doubt their reading speed would match and probably
exceed (since there are fewer symbols per average word to process) those who
are taught T.O, and I doubt it would be greatly affected by the words a Brit
would spell differently from an American. I admit I have no studies to base
that statement upon. Perhaps, the dialects of English speakers are more
widely varied than I realize.

> No one has really studied how long it would take for someone to
> regain their reading speed in a new orthography because it is
> probably more than the 3 weeks -- the typical limit for
> psychological research where students are the subjects.
>

PG: The dead weight of existing readers, once again.

> Paige wrote: [Once standdardized] "the alphabet stops being a
> relatively accurate representation of speech and over time the
> divergence between spoken English and written English will
> inevitably increase, and given enough time, we will be back in the
> same boat we are in now."
>
> SB: This is true and is precisely the argument Johnson used for not
> making an attempt to align print and speech at the time of the 1755
> standardization.

PG: I do not understand the foregoing. Tell us more about the "1755
standardization." Who did it and by what authority? Are you referring to
the publication of Johnson's dictionary? It seems to me that when such a
standardization took place, it would have been the perfect time to correct
the differences between spoken and written English that existed then. Or
was Johnson's point that the divergence is inevitable anyway, so we might as
well give up on the idea of keeping an alphabet in sync with people's
pronunciation?

> Standardized spelling will need to have minor revisions every 50
> years or so. At least that has been the experience with languages
> that attempt to preserve their alphabets such as Spanish and
> Portuguese.

PG: That sounds fine to me, but who has the authority to enforce such
changes each half-century. By the way, that is a long enough period, that
it probably would not bother most people if it only happened once in their
life-time.

> Given the divergence of of English dialects, standardization may
> include the use of [purposely ambiguous] symbols that have different
> interpretations in different regions. Phonemically, the short o may
> refer to BBC-English but as standardized it may also be interpreted
> as the NBC-English [ah].
>
> If there is a terminal R in the standardized spelling, non-rhotic
> speakers will ignore it the same way they ignore it in the
> traditional spelling. One could have a symbol that had three
> interpretations: either schwa, or schwa r, or syllabic r.

PG: Just out of curiosity: the presence of an "r" in T.O. presumably
indicates the letter was pronounced at one time, even by those who are now
non-rhotic speakers. After all, the English wrote these words down first
when there were no Americans around. I assume spelling has an effect upon
pronunciation so it seems odd to me that people would just stop pronouncing
phonemes that were originally part of the word. Does this change go back to
a period when most people were illiterate? Do linguists have any theories
as to why this occurs?

> The point is that in a world english, the divergence between speech
> communities is probably greater than the divergence from the alphbet
> that would be observed after a 50 year time interval.
>
> Regards,
>
> Steve
>
